objects.author: BrieAnna J. Frank
objects.title: 'This is a long-haul thing': ASU, UA discuss COVID-19 campus outbreaks, brace for possible spike
objects.html:
Both Arizona State University and University of Arizona held virtual meetings Wednesday morning to discuss COVID-19 outbreaks among their students and staff in addition to detailing the efforts they were taking to protect their communities from widespread infection.

UA President Robert C. Robbins opened the call by noting they hadn't intended on having a public briefing this week, but opted to reverse course after they witnessed a number of people ignoring recommended health protocols.

"We certainly expect there will be a spike (in cases) based on activities we've observed over the last week and over the weekend," he said.

As of the first week of September, Robbins said officials have visited 13 homes from nine different neighborhoods in the university area after receiving complaints that their occupants were violating city ordinances or public health guidelines.

Robbins said he saw data showing that 10 out of 21 people who were at one house tested positive for the virus, while 15 out of 35 tested positive in another.

He added that there were "major issues" at three fraternity or sorority houses, but said the university was working closely with those houses to address the problem. He said the university would not be releasing the names of the fraternities or sororities with outbreaks, citing student privacy.

"These numbers just show to me that we're not doing a good job of controlling the transmission of the virus," he said.

Ninety-one students were in isolation housing as of Wednesday with 90 of those living on-campus, according to Robbins. The university has 417 isolation beds.

He also expressed concern about the approaching flu season, saying that the university would "strongly encourage, if not mandate" everyone at the university to get a flu shot.

Though he acknowledged the university previously focused on educating students about COVID-19 mitigation strategies, which included hiring monitors to remind students about safety guidelines, he said the school might have to change its approach.

"We've educated, we've given everybody a chance," he said. "Now this has risen to a level where I think we need more strict intervention."

Robbins said he was not aware of any case where a student was disciplined for violating health guidelines.

He added that university teams were working to eventually test each dorm three times per week and expand wastewater-based epidemiology testing off-campus.

Dr. Teresa Cullen, Pima County Public Health director, said there would be "very, very aggressive testing" in various locations around Tucson over the next two weeks, saying that the health department's goal is a "COVID-resilient community."

Cullen called recent data "alarming" and echoed Robbins' statements about an inevitable spike in cases, saying that their focus would be on mitigating its impact as much as possible.

Dr. Richard Carmona, head of the university's reentry task force, said the school was at a "critical juncture" and will have to "shut things down" if the anticipated spike comes to fruition.

"We recognize we may have to make those decisions very shortly, depending on how these numbers continue to roll out," he said.

The university earlier reported that it had a total of 397 positive cases out of 15,310 tests done as of Sept. 3.

ASU believes it's 'off to a good start' but bracing for the 'long haul'

ASU President Michael Crow spent the first few minutes of the Wednesday morning meeting going through the timeline of the measures the university took to mitigate COVID-19 spread after getting its first reported case in January.

He said the university's approach has been to make testing available to anyone who wants or needs it, and implementing a daily health check for anyone coming onto campus. The school's plan also includes mandatory testing for some individuals, such as student-athletes, and random surveillance testing.

"We believe that we're off to a good start," Crow said. "We've got good educational outcomes, good management of positive cases that we have within the student body both on and off-campus, we've got very few employees who are testing positive."

Also on the call was Joanne Vogel, vice president of student services, who said that 146 ASU students in isolation as of Tuesday.

Crow defended the school's decision to, until that point, report only active COVID-19 cases instead of the cumulative total.

"We're very concerned that the message being sent out to the public is that everybody who's ever tested positive is positive," he said.

He added that the school planned on adding cumulative data to its website by the end of the day on Wednesday.

5 things we learned from the first presidential debate 6 restaurants and bars that closed permanently in September First phase of Peoria's 120-acre park opens Saturday A body cavity search left her bleeding. Police don't even consider it a use of force

Crow said there's a "very low probability" of someone contracting COVID-19 on one of ASU's campuses if they follow physical distancing guidelines and wear masks. He added that the school tracks cellphone density and Wi-Fi usage to prevent large groups from congregating.

When asked what circumstances would prompt the university to pivot back to an all-virtual model, Crow said that option would be explored if, for example, the supply of accommodations for students with COVID-19 did not meet the demand or there was increasing community spread within the university.

Crow stressed that the university will continue to employ these measures even after a COVID-19 vaccine is available.

"This is a long-haul thing for us," he said.

ASU earlier in the week announced that 807 students were known to have COVID-19 as of Sunday, a decrease from the 957 students reported on Thursday.

The number of employees with the virus also decreased from 26 to 18.

ASU had a positivity rate of about 2.3%, according to data reported Thursday. A positivity rate of 5% is considered a good benchmark that the spread is under control.

Of the 807 students sick as of Sunday, about 71% lived off-campus in the Phoenix area, according to ASU. Officials said 202 were in isolation on the Tempe campus, down from 369 last week.

Republic reporter Kaila White contributed to this article.

Reach the reporter at bfrank@arizonarepublic.com or 602-444-8529. Follow her on Twitter @brieannafrank.
